title: Roman Aqueducts: Engineering at Scale
description: A quick, practical guide to Roman Aqueducts: Engineering at Scale.

hook.text: Rome's 11 aqueducts delivered 1 million cubic meters of water dailyâ€”more per capita than many modern European cities.

buildup.text: Aqueducts used gravity alone: a precise gradient of 1-3 meters per kilometer moved water over distances up to 90 km.

discovery.text: The iconic arched bridges were a small fraction. Over 80% of aqueduct channels ran underground to prevent fouling.

twist.text: Romans didn't invent aqueductsâ€”Assyrians and Greeks did first. Rome's edge was scale: 500 km feeding one city.

climax.text: Some Roman aqueducts still carry water today, 2,000 years later. Modern engineers study them for lessons in durability.

punchline.text: Gravity moved an ocean of water without a single pump.

quiz.question: What was Rome's true innovation with aqueducts compared to earlier civilizations?
options: The unprecedented scale: 500 km of channels feeding one city
The invention of the arched bridge to carry water
Using lead pipes for the first time in history
